title-group.subtitle: Accounting for Strategic Product-Mix Interactions in Marketing Simulation Games

author-notes.corresp: James N. Cannon, Department of Accounting, Iowa State University, 2330 Gerdin Business Building, Ames, IA 50011-1350, USA Email: jcannon@iastate.edu

abstract.p: Business simulation game designers typically ignore product line interactions in the design of marketing simulation games. This article addresses the failing by modeling Rust, Zeithaml, and Lemon’s concept of the profitable-product death spiral, a product-mix interaction theory based on the concept of customer lifetime value (CLV). According to their theory, marketers often enter a cycle of decreasing demand by deleting less profitable products. When customers seek multiple products from the same company, the deletion of less profitable ones will often reduce demand for more profitable products as well, rendering them less profitable. Unchecked, the cycle continues until the company fails. This article discusses how to model the “death-spiral” effect by adapting Teach’s gravity-flow model to evaluate the product mix as a kind of “meta-product,” where desired products function as product attributes.

body.p: Over the years, simulation game designers have paid little attention to the modeling of product-mix strategy. While most marketing games include more than one product, implying a product mix, our review of the literature on business simulation design revealed no studies discussing a theoretical basis for modeling the effects of product-mix interactions, and hence, strategic product-mix decisions.

Recent developments in the areas of customer lifetime value (CLV) and customer equity (CE) provide the missing theory. On the surface, orienting oneself to the concept of CLV is simply a logical extension of conventional marketing. If marketing efforts are able to win customers for a company, what could be more logical than examining the value of these customers? However, conventional marketing and simulation games that model the marketing process measure success in terms of profit, generally breaking profit down by product and division. This is a legacy of the manufacturers’ dominance of marketing, particularly in consumer marketing. When companies begin breaking profit down by customer, including the discounted value of future sales, the conception of a product changes. Manufacturers begin to think much more like retailers, where the “product” is the assortment of products and services that customers expect to find when going shopping. This assortment provides the basis for formulating a product-mix strategy.

While the literature on simulation and gaming contains some work addressing retail issues (e.g., see Bacon & Pike, 1993; Haverty, 1990; Keyt & Cadotte, 1981), none addresses the problem of product-mix strategy. Furthermore, notwithstanding the fact that the notion of a desired product assortment is more naturally related to retailer than manufacturer decisions, retailers are vulnerable to the same profit-oriented traps as manufacturers. The concept of CLV contributes to decision making by providing the insight, that is, the notion that one cannot measure the success of marketing efforts by simply looking at profit for a single, arbitrarily defined product or period. Actual businesses, and students playing marketing simulation games, make investments and engage in marketing programs, the full benefit of which often does not pay out in the 1st year. According to CLV, decision makers will seek to maximize the return on these program investments. Both the expected life of customers and the amount of future sales depend on the marketer finding an ideal portfolio of products and services that consumers would like to purchase from them.

CLV focuses company attention on the customer rather than on the company’s products. While marketing theorists and practitioners have promoted this idea ever since the advent of the “marketing concept” and the ascendancy of customer orientation in the late 1950s, CLV gives customer-oriented marketing efforts a new meaning. Conventional customer orientation grew out of the concept of market segmentation. It meant studying customers and positioning products to meet customers’ needs (Smith, 1956). The associated metric is segment profitability, which in turn is driven by the profitability of the individual products targeted to the segment. Adopting the concept of CLV and focusing on relationship marketing leads to product portfolios that will drive sales and maximize “share of wallet.”

Perhaps the best way to illustrate the difference between the traditional profit-driven metric and CLV, or its composite effect, CE, is through what Rust, Zeithaml, and Lemon (2000) characterize as the “profitable-product death spiral.” It states that conventional companies often seek to measure profitability by product, using this heuristic as an index of benefit to both the company and the customers. As companies suffer from increasingly stringent budgetary constraints, they become more and more demanding of their product managers to deliver profitability. As a consequence, managers drop the less profitable products, ignoring the fact that customers typically want an assortment of products, and that the deletion may weaken assortments that customers want. The resulting loss of sales weakens demand for previously profitable products, subsequently causing them to be dropped. This weakens the assortments even further, and so forth in a downward death spiral. By focusing on customer rather than on product profitability, marketers look at the portfolios of products their customers want rather than disrupting portfolios for the sake of individual product profitability.

This article will build on a CLV framework developed by Cannon, Cannon, and Schwaiger (2010) to discuss a method of modeling strategic product-mix decisions in a simulation game environment. We will illustrate the effects of the model by discussing how it exposes players to the profitable-product death spiral.

Equation (1) is a simplistic representation of a single customer’s CLV. Although the equation gets more complicated, it is conceptually the same when you account for multiple market segments and relax the assumption that there is zero probability that customers will defect. Equation (2) introduces three additional variables: J number of segments, L retention probability, and Q quantity sold to new customers (Cannon et al., 2010). The addition of Q requires the substitution of R– (the average revenue per unit Q) for the original value of R (revenue per customer) used in Equation (1).

Equation (2) still maintains some simplifying assumptions. For example, customer segments would clearly include customers whose life expectancy will differ one from another. The equation implies that a segment average life expectancy will suffice. If necessary, one could add a defection rate parameter that would account for varying customer life expectancies (although we believe that this introduces unnecessary complexity, given the objective of the simulation).

In addition, Equation (2) implies that the cost of customer retention is zero. While this is unrealistic, a CLV analysis would typically accompany a relationship-marketing strategy. One of the key elements of such a marketing strategy is to exploit lower transaction costs by growing sales with existing customers (Cannon & Schwaiger, 2005). One could add an additional cost allocation for customer retention that would then reduce the attrition rate parameter mentioned above, further complicating the calculations. However, so long as retention costs do not exceed the cost of attracting a comparable new customer, the simplifying assumption does not detract from the premise.

sec.title: The Profitable-Product Death Spiral
sec.p: We have suggested above that a good way to illustrate the increased importance of product-mix strategy is through Rust et al.’s (2000) concept of the “profitable-product death spiral.” By using a heuristic that ignores product line interactions to increase a company’s earnings performance, managers prune the product line and precipitate a chain of events that not only decreases profits, but eventually destroys the company.

When put under pressure to increase profits, managers will often evaluate products according to their profitability, generally measured as some form of return on investment. Figure 1 illustrates such an analysis. Recognizing that marketing resources are constrained, managers establish a threshold for eliminating less profitable investments. Those investments whose profitability exceeds the threshold are retained, while those falling below are deleted from the product line, thus focusing and preserving resources for applications that have the greatest profit impact.

caption.p: Product-pruning according to the profitable-product heuristic
Source: Adapted from Rust, Zeithaml, and Lemon (2000).

sec.p: Heuristically, this makes sense, but it ignores the fact that products are rarely purchased in isolation. In the case of a retail operation, this is obvious because people generally enter a store to purchase an assortment rather than a single product. But even for manufacturers, umbrella brands typically seek to exploit brand equity by incorporating multiple products within the same brand umbrella. For example, if you have come to trust Craftsman tools, as a consumer, you expect the company to provide a tool for virtually any application. If you buy an electric drill, you expect the company to offer compatible drill bits. By failing to offer a particular bit, the company will not only lose the sale of the bit, but also lose the sale of the drill to the customers who would have bought the bit. By continually pruning product lines to include only the most profitable products, the company continually erodes its customer base until no products have a large enough base to be profitable.

Rust offers a personal example of how this works using a textbook he had written that was accompanied by a readings book. The textbook sold well, but the readings book did not, so the publisher discontinued the readings book. The problem was that many of the textbook adopters dropped Rust’s textbook because the readings book was no longer available (Rust et al., 2000). Extending the logic, the publisher would feel additional pressure on its profits and would respond by cutting other less-popular features of the textbook package, thus alienating additional subgroups of adopters. In the end, the text itself would no longer be selling well, and it too would be deleted from the publisher’s line.

Figures 2, 3, and 4 illustrate the scenario. Let us begin by imagining a textbook (Product A), supported by 12 additional ancillaries and support options (Products B through M). For the sake of simplicity, assume that these are used by 4 different segments of professors, each teaching courses with a different support package. For instance, Segment 1 wants Products A, B, D, E, F, G, and J. The segments consist of 20,000 students each, yielding a customer base for Product A of 80,000. The base for B through E would be 60,000, the base for F through I would be 40,000, and the base for J through M would be 20,000.

caption.p: Demand potential for the 13 related textbook products
Demand potential for 13 related textbook products, arranged by segment
Demand potential for 13 related textbook products for a different set of segments

sec.p: Figure 2 arranges the products by volume, following the logic of the profitable-product heuristic described in Figure 1. As competitors enter the market, shares within each of the product categories begin to fall, and the publisher takes a relatively conservative approach, deleting only the four products with the very weakest sales—Products J, K, L, and M. This is the classic product-centered response that Rust describes.

Figure 3 rearranges the analysis by segment, showing who is using each of the ancillaries to Textbook A. Note that it does not change any of the numbers. Demand potential still ranges from a high of 80,000 students for the core product to 20,000 students for the least-used ancillaries. However, it shows us how demand is distributed. This is critical, because Figure 3 indicates that every one of the deleted products is part of the support package used by one of the segments. This suggests that eliminating four low-potential products threatens the sales of every one of the remaining products!

One common strategy for addressing the situation portrayed in Figure 3 is to “bundle” the products. This increases volume for weak products by forcing all segments to purchase them, whether or not the products are needed. This works in many cases because the added volume of less-popular products enables the company to offer a low-enough price that segments do not begrudge the extra products they have to buy. Nevertheless, in a highly competitive market, such tactics are likely to fail. The company that uses them will be overcome by competitors who specialize in the various segments, giving them lower prices, including only the products they want.

By contrast, Figure 4 portrays a different segmentation structure than Figure 3. It indicates that all of the deleted products are being used by a single, obviously less profitable segment. Eliminating the low-profit products would eliminate only one segment, at a cost of 20,000 units of Product A in addition to 20,000 units of each weak product.

The argument, of course, is that only by shifting from a product-centered to a customer-centered marketing approach (Bell, Deighton, Reinartz, Rust, & Swartz, 2002; Rust, Zeithaml, & Lemon, 2004) will the implications of this kind of strategic product-mix decision become clear. The customer-centered approach shifts the focus from profitability by brand to profitability by customer. To do this, the strategy recognizes that customer profitability is driven not by products, but by bundles of benefits derived by an entire portfolio of products and services.

sec.title: Modeling the outcomes of product-mix strategy
sec.p: In order to model product-mix strategy, we will seek to introduce simple modifications to a standard simulation platform, referred to as the “Gold standard” (Cannon and Schwaiger 2005). Gold (2005) proposes a system-dynamic-based model that draws on well-accepted economic theory in an effort to avoid incompatibilities created by individual biases and disciplinary conventions. He argues that the basic components of market structure should be represented in a standardized economic form, with demand systems in the form of an aggregate demand function and supply in the form of aggregate production of the various firms simulated in the game. At the firm level, supply and demand systems are represented through the basic components of a profit equation. That is, a firm’s activities will be reflected in a share of market demand, compared with the supply provided, along with the firm’s associated variable and fixed costs. The basic macro- and micro-economic system is the same for virtually any game. Additional components, such as the one we are suggesting in this paper, can be added by establishing linkages to the appropriate equations in the larger macro- and micro-systems.

Specifically, Gold suggests that demand can be derived from market share, which, in turn, is a function of the product’s relative price, marketing expenditures, and market fit (similarity of product attributes to those desired by a particular market segment). The relative impact of each of these demand input variables is adjusted according to a nonlinear response function, defined by parameters as set forth by Gold and Pray (1984).

By applying the Gold standard to our design efforts, we hope to minimize the number of design modifications simulation designers would need to make when incorporating the profitable-product-death-spiral phenomenon into the product-profit and CLV frameworks within their games.

Our approach addresses the impact of the product mix on product profit by incorporating it into Gold’s product-market fit variable (Dj). This, in turn, fits directly into Gold’s primary demand equation.

The simplest way to introduce the product mix into the CLV model is through the retention probability variable (L) in the existing CE Equation (2). Increases in CE constitute an increase in current period performance. Using this as a performance metric in the game motivates game participants to focus on optimizing the product mix.

According to Cannon, Cannon, and Schwaiger (2010), retention probability also depends on Dj. They suggest that L should be a function of past customer loyalty (as measured by the prior period’s retention probability variable), relative price advantage, relative product-mix fit, and relative budget performance, as shown in Equation (3).

The Gold standard for addressing product-market fit follows Teach’s (1984, 1990) multiattribute “gravity-flow” demand model. That is, it assumes that each segment of the market has an ideal product, defined by its product attributes. Just as gravitational attraction decreases with distance, so the relative desirability of a brand decreases with the Euclidean distance between its attributes and those of the segment’s ideal. Following this logic, the relative attractiveness of the product/service portfolio a company offers can be expressed as a function of the Euclidean distance between the company’s offering and the ideal established for a particular segment. A customer’s desired portfolio becomes a kind of meta-product, where the desired products are analogous to the customer’s desired product attributes.

We may apply this logic in stages, designing games that will focus solely on the issue of product mix, or by adding refinements, that will combine product-mix issues with conventional product positioning. In each case, our objective will be to translate the quality of a company’s product-mix decisions into a distance measure (Dj) that will provide product fit in Gold’s standard demand equation and the customer-retention measure developed in Equations (3) through (6).

In the simplest conception, we would assume that all the products in the company’s product mix are of the highest quality and fully address consumers’ needs. In such a case, the only factor determining product-mix fit (our “meta-product”) is whether the company offers a product that fulfills a segment’s requirement, thereby focusing product strategy on the product mix. Translating this into Teach’s concept of a gravity-flow model, the distance equation would include an indicator variable specifying whether a desired product is offered as part of the company’s meta-product.

A meta-product would typically contain a core product (defining the product category) with a value of “1,” and ancillary products/services having values of “0” or “1.” In this conception, the use of nominal variables suggests that the more commonly used Euclidean-distance measure would be replaced with a city-block distance (see Anderberg, 1973; Jobson, 1992). Teach (1984) notes that the city-block is an acceptable method for measuring fit. Euclidean distance returns a positive number by summing the square root of the squared distance between the ideal and the actual product attributes, as illustrated by Equation (9) below. If the attributes are either “0” or “1,” using the city-block measure returns a positive distance by summing the absolute value of the difference between the ideal and actual, as illustrated in Equation (7).
where
Ii,j = the components of the ideal product portfolio for segment j, with “1” indicating that product i was included in the portfolio and “0” indicating that it was not
di = the components of the actual product portfolio, with “1” indicating that product i was included in the portfolio and “0” indicating that it was not

nj = the total number of products included in the ideal portfolio for segment j. (nj + 1 represents a fictitious product for which the ideal value [Ii,j] is always “1” and for which the value of the product’s attribute [di] is always “0,” thus ensuring that the ideal and a company’s actual product mix are never identical and the value of Di is never zero).

Note that the calculation of Dj is a measure of distance and defines the denominator for the measure of product fit in Equation (5) above, used in calculations of customer retention. If a company’s product mix provided a perfect match to a segment’s ideal, the value of Dj would be zero. Given that we cannot divide by zero, the demand and customer-retention equations would become undefined. Teach (1984) addresses this problem in his development of the gravity-flow model by adding an extra, imperfect attribute to every product. Following his suggestion, we have added a single, nonmatching element to each segment’s ideal product portfolio (meta-product), so Dj never reaches zero.

Equation (7) only considers those (nj) products that are included in segment j’s ideal product portfolio. This is a subset of a larger number (n) of products that a company might include in its product mix. By considering only “ideal” products in Equation (7), we are not penalizing a company for offering products that segment members do not want. Customers rarely object to a company offering too many products. The penalty for offering unwanted products comes from the costs associated with maintaining these products in the company’s product mix. Indeed, it is the desire to avoid these costs that causes companies to fall prey to the profitable-product death spiral.

Moving to another stage of complexity, we recognize that not all products contribute equal value to our conceptualization of an “ideal” portfolio. Unequal values can be incorporated into the calculation of fit by assigning a relative importance value, wi,j, to weight each ideal-actual evaluation for a segment j. We can use this to simplify Equation (7), calculating Dj directly, as shown in Equation (8). The equation no longer limits the potential components of the actual product portfolio (di) to those components included in the ideal product portfolio, but considers all (n) possible products, simply giving them a relative importance value (wi,j) of “0” in cases where they are not part of the ideal portfolio.
where

wi,j = a weighting factor (between “0” and “1”) representing the relative importance of product i in segment j’s ideal product portfolio. (wn+1,j = 0.05, assuring that the distance will never reach zero)
n = the total number of products available for production in the game

Again, we follow Teach’s (1984) convention by adding a fictitious product that is not present in the company’s product mix. This adds “1” to the total distance. We suggest assigning a relatively low weight to the fictitious product. For example, if wn+1,j is 0.05, the value of Dj for a “perfect fit” would become (1× 0.05 =) 0.05 instead of zero.

As a final refinement, we can relax the assumption that all products fully address consumers’ needs. In a more complex game, the designer might want to conceptualize each ideal product as varying in desirability to the segment, depending not only on the importance of its inclusion in the product mix, but also on its individual attributes. In this case, the presence of product i in a company’s product mix would no longer be represented by a value for di,j of “0” or “1,” but rather, a value for di,j that ranges from “0” to “1,” depending on the fit between each product in the mix and the corresponding segment ideal. This is a direct application of Teach’s (1984, 1990) gravity-flow model to individual products. The value of di,j would be expressed as shown in Equation (9):
where
di,j = the individual product fit of product i relative to the corresponding ideal within the portfolio for segment j
Ii,j,k = the ideal level of attribute k relative to product i in segment j
vi,j,k = a factor (greater than “0”) representing the relative importance of attribute k associated with product i in segment j’s portfolio
ai,k = the level of attribute k possessed by product i in the company’s product mix

m = the total number of attributes. (m+1 represents a fictitious attribute whose importance [vm+1] is always “1,” for which the ideal value [Im+1] is always “1,” and for which the value of the product’s attribute [ai,k] is always “0,” analogous to n+1 in Equations (7) and (8)).

The Equation (9) conceptualization does not use nominal values for di,j, but the maximum value still approaches “1.” If a product matches the ideal, the value of the denominator will be zero for every attribute except m+1, whose value would be 1, resulting in a di,j value of 1.0. A product that is deficient in any of its attributes will have a value of ai,k that is less than the ideal, thus increasing the value of the denominator in Equation (9), reducing the value of di,j.

This means that we can still use the logic of Equation (8) to calculate the overall value of a company’s product fit (Dj) for segment j. Any lapses in the quality of products included in the company’s mix, as determined by Equation (9), simply weaken the mix’s overall product fit. Given that the value of di,j is not limited to “0” or “1,” the city-block metric no longer applies, so the equation would use a Euclidean-distance measure, as shown in Equation (10):

To summarize, Equations (8) and (10) both model the customer segment’s desired product portfolio. The choice of equation depends on whether the simulation addresses individual product attributes in addition to the mere presence of products in a company’s product mix. The value of product-market fit (Dj) always falls between “0.00” (adjusted to a small number, such as “0.05”) and “1.00,” where “0.05” is a perfect market fit. Players would seek to enhance their performance by formulating and selecting products (represented by nonzero values for di,j) for the company’s product mix that would best address the needs of their targeted segments. As the value of Dj increases, customers defect to other suppliers. The equations discussed in this section address the demand side of the firm’s economic equation. The framework acquires a strategic imperative when we impose financial constraints on the development of product assortments. By making products subject to relatively large economies of scale, low-volume products are likely to incur financial losses. In terms of Gold’s (2005) standardized model, this could be easily accomplished through any number of simple adjustments to the companies’ cost functions. The prospect of losses motivates players to trim unprofitable products, thus setting the stage for the “death-spiral” phenomenon if they do not consider product-mix interactions.

sec.p: In order to illustrate how the product-death-spiral model might work in practice, consider the textbook marketing situation portrayed in Figure 3. Table 1 provides information regarding products, segment size, product preferences, and total demand. This information (with the exception of the “fictitious product” N) would be available in the form of a “research” report for the game participants to use.

sec.p: The cells in the center of the table report relative preference for products by each segment (wij). A product that does not fit the segment’s ideal product portfolio has a preference of “0.” For reporting convenience, the right-hand column provides the total potential unit demand across segments. The number in parentheses indicates the total number of potential customers in each segment.

The report containing the information portrayed in Table 1 represents market data that would realistically be available to managers in a marketing organization. In an actual business, estimates of segment size and preferences are commonly obtained from market research, as are estimates of demand potential by product.

Applying the data in Table 1 to Equation (8), the value for Segment 1 would be based on Products A, B, D, E, F, G, and J. If a company provided all of these products, the value of D1 would be 0.050 (0.000 + 0.050 for the fictitious product, N). If the company were to drop product J, the distance would increase to (0.050 + 0.178 =) 0.228. Each product that gets dropped increases the distance, thus decreasing the relative attractiveness of the product in Gold’s demand equation and the customer-retention measure developed in Equations (3) through (6). The total relative attractiveness for each segment determines the unit sales each textbook package will achieve in each segment, and ultimately, the package’s share of total demand.

Of course, the relative advantage of offering one set of products versus another depends on the attractiveness of the segment(s). This, in turn, depends on segment size, the synergy among segments (the number of desired products held in common), the other costs associated with serving the segments, and the competition. In order to give the selection of meta-products strategic significance, the game must impose a cost structure so that products are subject to relatively large economies of scale, causing low-volume products to incur financial losses. The information contained in Table 1 includes segment size and the information needed to calculate product fit. The full effect (i.e., resulting profit impact) of reduced customer retention due to poor product fit depends on Gold’s (2005) demand and cost equations. We leave the illustration of demand and cost characteristic effects on the profitable-product death spiral to future research.

sec.title: Summary and Conclusion
sec.p: The purpose of this article has been to address the incorporation of product-mix strategy into computer-based marketing simulations. By this, we mean the inclusion of product-mix interactions in the demand function, where we assume that consumers prefer to buy multiple products from a single vendor, rather than creating their own assortment from several different sources.

The importance of this kind of product interaction is increasing in today’s marketing environment. Many marketers are seeking to compensate for falling margins, resulting from decreased product differentiation, by using relationship marketing to lower transaction costs and increase the sales per customer. The task of the game designer is to reward players for making decisions that are consistent with this trend. As suggested by our discussion of Figures 1 to 4, players should invest in products that enable them to deliver the product assortments desired by as many customers as possible. Implicitly, they would need to strategically focus on those segments whose needs tend to overlap, as suggested by Davidow and Uttal (1989). This is illustrated in the difference between the unfocused segments illustrated in Figure 3 versus the focused ones portrayed in Figure 4, where focusing on Segments 5 to 7 enables the company to delete the weak products from its line with minimal impact on sales.

To implement this approach in a gaming situation, players need to be given research information on the ideal product portfolios for each of the available market segments. This is given in Table 1. The preference data allow players to prioritize products for each segment. The product-mix data enable them to categorize products into customer preference portfolios, thus avoiding a profitable-product death spiral.

A second requirement is to create algorithms within the game that reward players for strategically focusing on compatible market segments, and for creating product and service mixes to address these segments. We have described such an algorithm, treating product mixes as a kind of meta-product where the included products are “product attributes.” The value for different meta-products varies by segment. As we have noted, in order to give the selection of meta-products strategic significance, the game must impose a cost structure that causes low-volume products to incur financial losses. Thus, players are forced to prune products if they are to succeed financially. However, if they fail to consider product interactions, and ultimately to focus their segmentation strategy, competitive pressures will erode sales by means of an increase in Dj from Equation (8), resulting in a lower relative product-market fit, from Equation (5), and ultimately, falling customer retention, from Equation (3).

Note that the algorithm we have used does not actually model product interactions. It simply defines the relative desirability of product assortments for a given segment. That is, it models the interaction between segment membership and product preferences. In fact, product interactions often exist in actual marketing situations. For instance, to use the textbook example, some segments may have a high preference for a student workbook and a related set of video/lecture materials keyed to the exercises contained in the workbook. If the workbook were eliminated, this would also change the desirability of the associated video/lecture materials to the segment’s portfolio.

We have chosen not to address the problem of product interactions within a portfolio, because we believe that the product-preference algorithm we have suggested would be adequate to handle product-mix strategy issues for most situations we can envision. Indeed, an analogous issue exists regarding product attribute interactions as well, where the overall impact of attributes tends to be evaluated using some kind of a distance measure (e.g., our Equation (9)). To illustrate, segment preferences for a textbook containing a glossary would drop dramatically if the book were written without the use of many technical terms. However, as a rule, a segment that valued a glossary would also value technical terms, so strategic decision makers would be motivated to include both or neither in their product design, depending on the segments they were targeting.

If a simulation were to address a specialized situation where product interactions became a meaningful issue, this would have to be addressed in a separate article. The article would be highly relevant to the mainstream marketing literature as well as to the literature on simulation and gaming.

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: James N. Cannon is an assistant professor of accounting in the College of Business at Iowa State University. He holds a PhD from the University of Utah, an MBA from the University of Michigan, and a BA from Brigham Young University. Prior to his appointment, he held various financial analyst positions at Visteon Automotive Systems and Hewlett-Packard Corporation.

Hugh M. Cannon is the Adcraft/Simons-Michelson Professor of marketing at Wayne State University. He holds PhD, MPhil, and MBA degrees from New York University and an AB from Brigham Young University. He also serves on the Board of Directors of the Association for Business Simulation and Experiential Learning (ABSEL) and as dean of fellows of that professional society.

Manfred Schwaiger is university professor of business administration and dean of studies at the Munich School of Management, Ludwig-Maximilians-University of Munich (LMU). He holds a doctoral and a postdoctoral degree from Augsburg University. He is chair of the Institute for Market-Based Management at LMU and is a member of several company advisory boards. He also serves as member of the board of the German Academic Association for Business Research (VHB).
